_comment: Climate Risk Scenario - Warm Winters Impact
_description: This case models the impact of climate change on Engelberg's tourism patterns. Warmer winters reduce ski season demand (winter occupancy -25%), while warmer summers increase hiking/outdoor activity demand (summer occupancy +10%). This tests the resilience of the investment to changing climate patterns.

_case_metadata.description: Warm winters: -25% winter occupancy. Warmer summers: +10% summer occupancy. Tests climate change impact.

financing._explanation: Financing assumptions remain the same as base case.

rental._explanation: Rental assumptions remain the same as base case, except for seasonal occupancy adjustments.

seasonal._explanation: Seasonal occupancy rates adjusted to reflect climate change impacts: reduced winter ski demand and increased summer outdoor activity demand.

winter_peak.name: Winter Peak (Ski Season)
winter_peak._occupancy_rate_explanation: 52.5% occupancy (down from 70% base case, -25% reduction). Warmer winters reduce reliable snow cover and ski season demand. This represents a significant climate risk for Engelberg's primary tourism driver.

summer_peak.name: Summer Peak (Hiking Season)
summer_peak._occupancy_rate_explanation: 77% occupancy (up from 70% base case, +10% increase). Warmer, longer summers increase hiking and outdoor activity demand. More favorable weather extends the hiking season and attracts more visitors.

offpeak.name: Off-Peak (Shoulder Seasons)
offpeak._occupancy_rate_explanation: 70% occupancy (unchanged from base case). Shoulder seasons are less affected by climate changes.

expenses._explanation: Expense assumptions remain the same as base case.

tax._explanation: Tax assumptions for calculating after-tax returns on investment property income in Switzerland.
tax._marginal_tax_rate_explanation: 21% marginal tax rate for rental income. This represents the combined federal and cantonal tax rate applicable to investment property income in Switzerland.
tax._depreciation_rate_explanation: 2% annual depreciation rate on property value. In Switzerland, investment properties can be depreciated for tax purposes, typically 2-3% annually. This provides additional tax deductions beyond interest and operating expenses.

projection._explanation: Projection assumptions remain the same as base case.
